subject: Re: Ant for building native applications (Re: [junit] Sun doesn't  use JUni=  t. Why?)
msgSnippet: Having a precompiled task that does exactly what you want it to is only part of the solution.  When packaging for distribution, the sequence of steps is fixed
messageBody:
Having a precompiled task that does exactly what you want it to is only part of the
solution. When packaging for distribution, the sequence of steps is fixed and you
run through it once from start to finish. ant is pretty good for this.

When developing, you need a wide range of dependency tracking to ensure you're
doing as little work as possible in response to any given change (this assumes
you're using the same framework to build for development as you do for distribution).
Rapid changes in development are slowed down when you have to write code to
support changes in your build process. In this situation, make's dependencies and
script-level control are more well-suited.

Ant expects all tasks to have dependencies implicitly encoded in the task itself, if you
want to avoid the overhead of invoking a certain task. If I want to do simple
dependency checking to avoid a custom task (using exec or an aggregate of tasks) if
it's already been done, the solution with ant is verbose at best.

Think of it as GUI vs programmatic API or script. If everything you want to do is
already encoded in the GUI, that's great. If not, then it's no better and sometimes
worse than the alternatives.
